description: Ultimately from Anglo-Norman emparlance, from the verb Old French emparler.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Discussion, especially before some action is taken; conference, debate.
examples: There was on both sides much to say; / She'd hear the cause another day; / And so she did, and then a third, / She heard itâ€”there she kept her word; / But with rejoinder and replies, / Long bills, and answers, stuffed with lies / Demur, imparlance, and essoign, / The parties ne'er could issue join: / For sixteen yers the cause was spun, / And then stood where it first begun.

entries.meaning: (law, obsolete) Time given to a party to talk or converse with his opponent, originally with the object of effecting, if possible, an amicable adjustment of the suit, but also used to obtain further time to plead or answer allegations.
